metadata.title: Cerebral Palsy  Spastic Diplegia
synonyms: diplegia, spastic: cerebral palsy: spastic diplegic cerebral palsy
anatomical location body part affected: Cerebral palsy (CP) results from a cerebral lesion and affects the overall development of a child(8)
Diplegia is a form of CP that primarily affects bilateral lower extremities(14)
The presentation of the involvement of body segments may manifest itself differently as a child grows and develops(8)
description: Based on the agreement at the 2007 International Workshop on Definition and Classification of Cerebral Palsy, CP is a nonspecific term that describes “a group of permanent disorders of the development of movement and posture, causing activity limitations, that are attributable to non-progressive  disturbances that occurred in the developing fetal or infant brain”(14)
CP is the most common motor disability in childhood(55)
CP occurs in 2–2.5  per 1000 births in the industrialized world(69)

Spasticity is the most common neurological abnormality in CP that occurs in approximately 75% of all children with CP.(14) Diplegia is the most common form of spastic CP(14) –In spastic diplegic CP, the spasticity is present in and involves the lower extremities more compared to the upper extremities(14)

reimbursement: In the United States, depending on geographical location, individuals with CP might be eligible for state government-funded  therapy programs in the school, clinic, or home setting.(1) Evaluations to determine if a child qualifies for early intervention services through the state-funded  program are free for recipients. Children younger than 3 years are evaluated by local early intervention services; andthe3-year-old  or older children are evaluated through the local public school system. Reimbursement through private insurance will vary depending on the individual’s policy
presentation signs and symptoms: Spastic diplegic CP(14) –Hypertonicity is present, with increased co-contraction  of muscle groups  –The degree of spasticity varies in each child and can vary with the child’s activity –Agonist muscle groups often lose strength due to spasticity in the antagonist muscle group –Hyperreflexia –Primitive reflexes may persist –Atypical muscle tone –Gait impairments –Orthopedic complications may result from atypical muscle tone, spasticity, and persistent primitive reflexes which may include any of the following(2): -Hip/thigh: femoral anteversion, acetabular dysplasia, hip subluxation, hip dislocation, coxa valga, pelvic obliquity, soft tissue contractures (adductors, hamstrings, rectus femoris) -Spine: thoracolumbar scoliosis, lumbar lordosis -Scoliosis is often a C-shaped  curve (no compensatory curve) -Ankle/foot deformities: calcaneal varus or valgus, plantarflexion contractures -Patella alta (patella that is located more superiorly than typical) may occur if tightness of the quadriceps limits flexion of the knee(14) –Although lower extremities are more involved than upper extremities, spastic diplegia can manifest with varying degrees of hand function, and often the involvement is asymmetrical(8)

Patients with this diagnosis are at the risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention during the examination

causes: The cause is often obscure or multifactorial(56)

Congenital CP – occurs as a result of injury to the child’s brain before or during the birth–85–90%  of CP is congenital(55)–The specific cause is not known in many cases (55)–Perinatal asphyxia is a rare cause of congenital CP and typically is not associated with spastic diplegia

Acquired CP – occurs as a result of injury to the brain after birth within the first few years of the life (typically by age 2years). It can result from infection, traumatic brain injury (TBI), anoxia, or ischemia–Approximately 10% of cases of CP are acquired–Usually associated with an infection (e.g., meningitis) or head injury(55)
Approximately 20% of cases of CP are associated with known risk factors
pathogenesis: CP is a nonprogressive neuromuscular disorder caused by an injury to a region or multiple regions of the brain that resultsin permanent damage to the brain tissue(14)
The insult to the immature brain primarily affects the child’s postural mechanisms and muscle tone(3)
The mechanisms implicated in the pathogenesis of CP include ischemia, inflammation, and infection(57)

The pathogenesis of spasticity is related to involuntary hyperactivity of skeletal muscle associated with lesions of thedescending motor pathway–Hyperexcitability of the stretch reflex is one component–Recent study results suggest that neural mechanisms are not the only causes of increased muscle tone–Authors of a study conducted in Denmark showed that the changes in mechanical and morphological properties ofintracellular and extracellular tissues in muscle tendon and joints also occur due to lesions of the descending motorpathways and are difficult to distinguish from reflex-mediated changes(58)
risk factors prenatal: Prematurity/gestational age (before 32 weeks’(4)or 42 weeks’ or later during gestation)(5)

Low birth weight (less than 5 pounds and 8 ounces)(4)–Norwegian researchers compared birth measurements of 398 children diagnosed with CP compared to 490,022 typicallydeveloping children. Researchers concluded that low and high birth measurements increased the risk of childrenbeing diagnosed with CP, particularly spastic CP. Hemiplegic CP was associated with decreased birth length and headcircumference, whereas greater birth length and head circumference were associated with spastic quadriplegia anddyskinetic CP(65)
TORCH (toxoplasmosis, other infections [e.g.,, syphilis], rubella, cytomegalovirus, herpes) syndrome(71)
Mother and infant blood type incompatibility(71)

overall contraindications precautions: Clinicians should include the family/caregivers in the treatment sessions, explain and demonstrate the interventions, and provide verbal and written instruction as indicated

Patients with CP have an increased risk for fractures, which usually occur in the lower extremities. Clinicians must take appropriate precautions during physical therapy to minimize the risk of injury

Seizures are common in children with CP. During a seizure, the clinician should(7) stay with the patient eliminate dangerous objects from the area release restrictive clothing not hold down extremities use aspiration precautions: rotate head to the side, assess airway, wait for tonic-clonic  activity to pass before administering artificial respiration if indicated for additional information on patients who experience seizures, see the series of Clinical Reviews on epilepsy
Clinicians should be aware of any feeding tubes and take appropriate precautions during treatment

A patient with oral motor dysfunction may not be able to manage liquids/foods safely and may be at risk for aspiration. Consult with family, nurse, and/or speech-language pathologist (SLP) for diet and fluid restrictions
Patients with CP may be at risk for a respiratory compromise that can limit the ability to participate in the therapeutic activities

Consult with family/healthcare providers for restrictions/health care plan related to a diagnosis of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). Try to schedule therapy sessions either before a meal or several hours after a meal
In patients with shunts, monitor for signs/symptoms of shunt malfunction (e.g., seizures, irritability, headaches, vomiting)(8)

Clinicians should be aware that swallowing difficulties and breathing difficulties are rare but serious complications of botulinum toxin treatment can occur at any time during the first week after the treatment(59) If these complications occur, seek emergency medical care immediately

contraindications precautions to examina: Follow facility protocols for obtaining parental consent

Patients with this diagnosis are at the risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention during the examination ›History (History taking will vary slightly depending on the age at which the patient is presenting for evaluation)

History of present illness/injury –Etiology of illness -Obtain the birth history, including prenatal, perinatal, and postnatal periods -When was the child diagnosed? -What is the current reason for evaluation and treatment? -Has the child undergone any surgeries? If so, when? In the parents’ opinion, were they successful? -Inquire about any medical complications –Course of treatment -Medical management -Orthopedic surgery might be indicated for(9) -significant contractures -joint subluxation/dislocation -curvature of the spine affecting (or potential to affect) overall function and/or respiration -difficulty with ADLs, specifically hygiene and/or pain due to musculoskeletal deviations -Various surgeries may be used for the correction of flexed knee gait(60) -Lengthening of the hamstring muscles is accepted widely as the standard treatment(60) -Adverse events that have been reported after hamstring lengthening include genu recurvatum and increased anterior pelvic tilt(60) -Other common surgical procedures -Adductors, hip flexors, or gastrocsoleus lengthening -Dorsal rhizotomy to decrease spasticity -Pelvic osteotomy, femoral osteotomy for management of hip deformity -The patient’s medical team will determine how best to treat the patient’s spasticity. Generally, a reduction in spasticity is useful to the patient; however, in some instances, spasticity can facilitate function in otherwise weak muscles. The entire clinical picture should be evaluated before implementing any treatment strategies to reduce spasticity to avoid loss of function(10) -Spasticity management may consist of the following: (Note: the level of investigation into the efficacy of the following treatment methods varies) -Physical therapy/orthotic management(10) -Oral medications (e.g., diazepam)(10) -Chemodenervation – botulinum toxin, phenol, or alcohol injections(10) -Rhizotomy(10) -Intrathecal baclofen(10) -Orthopedic surgery(10) -Radial extracorporeal shock wave therapy (rESWT)(11) -Medications for current illness/injury -Determine what medications clinician has prescribed, if any and if they are taken? -Botulinum toxin, intrathecal baclofen, pamidronate (to increase bone mineral density), and glycopyrrolate (to reduce drooling) may be used -Anti-seizure  medications may be prescribed as indicated(12)  -Diagnostic tests completed: Diagnosis of CP is often made based on the patient’s history, clinical observation, and neurological testing. The diagnosis is based partly on excluding other neurological disorders and partly on following the child long enough to determine that the disorder is static and nonprogressive.(56) Testing may consist of the following: -MRI to assess location and size of brain injury(13) -Cranial ultrasound(14) -X-ray  to rule out orthopedic complications (e.g., scoliosis, femoral anteversion, hip dysplasia) -Electroencephalogram (EEG) assessment -Home remedies/alternative therapies:  Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture, Brain Gym, hyperbaric chamber treatment, myofascial structural integration).(15) What were they used for and if they were effective or not? -Previous therapy:  Document whether the patient has had speech, occupational, or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful. How long did the patient receive rehabilitation services? Is the child currently receiving any therapeutic interventions (school therapy, hippotherapy, hyperbaric chamber treatment)? Document the patient’s and family’s impressions of previous experiences with therapy and healthcare professionals(8) –Aggravating/easing factors  (and length of time each item is performed before the symptoms are aggravated or eased) -Document any factors that appear to exacerbate spasticity, seizures, or any other symptom -Document any factors that seem to ease symptoms, including spasticity, pain, or seizure activity –Body chart:  Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms –Nature of symptoms:  Document nature of symptoms (e.g., constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling). The specific cause of pain can be difficult to isolate, since pain can be caused by medical and/or surgical procedures; physical, occupational, and/or speech therapy treatments; and/or gastrointestinal, orthopedic, and/or neuromuscular disorders.(16) –Rating of symptoms -Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 0–10  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically, address if the pain is present now and how much) -The Oucher scale, a self-report  pain V AS, may be used with children aged 3.3 years and older(17) -Wong-Baker  FACES Pain Rating Scale for preschool-aged  children or FLACC scale, used commonly in acute care settings for nonverbal patients –Pattern of symptoms:  Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also, document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables –Sleep disturbance:  Document number of wakings/night, if any –Other symptoms:  Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to the physician (e.g., dizziness, bowel/bladder dysfunction, saddle anesthesia). In children with shunts, the clinician should monitor for signs and symptoms of shunt malfunction –Respiratory status:  Document if the patient has received or is receiving any respiratory therapy. Does the child have any history of respiratory problems? Any limitations in activity due to respiratory issues? –Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe __________________________

Medical history –Medical history -General inquiry -What is the patient’s current age and what is the adjusted age for prematurity? (When performing standardized tests, typically adjust for prematurity until the age of 2 years) -Any recent hospital stays? If so, how long was the patient hospitalized? -Who comprises the patient’s medical team? -Does the child require a feeding tube? -Has the patient undergone any surgical procedures? -Any spasticity management interventions, such as botulinum toxin, phenol, baclofen pump, etc.? -At what age were developmental milestones reached?  -Inquire about pregnancy and birth history. Note pertinent findings, including APGAR scores, gestational age, adjusted age, birth weight, need for and extent of respiratory support (e.g., CPAP, ventilator), manner of delivery, need for forceps or vacuum, nuchal cord complications, length of NICU stay, fetal exposure to alcohol or drugs, status upon discharge from hospital -Comorbid diagnoses/Other medical conditions:  Ask the patient/caregiver about other problems, including diabetes, obesity, cancer, epilepsy/seizures, heart disease, GERD, autism spectrum disorder (ASD), sensory processing disorder, attention deficit disorder, speech-language disorders, behavioral disorders, orthopedic disorders. Often blindness, deafness, sensory procession, attention deficit disorder, and ASD coexist(56) -Authors of a study in the United States reported a diagnosis of ASD occurred in 6.9% of 8-year-old  children with CP (n = 451), with a greater frequency among children with nonspastic CP compared to spastic CP. Also, 41% of these children with CP were diagnosed with epilepsy. The prevalence of CP in the year 2008 was 3.1 per 1,0008-year-old children in the United States. Data was collected from the Autism and Developmental Disabilities Monitoring Network, a population-based, record-review  surveillance system which monitors CP in four regions of the U.S.(64) -Medications previously prescribed:  Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including over-the-counter drugs and herbal supplements) -Other symptoms:  Ask patient/caregiver about other symptoms that may be inhibiting the child’s motor development

Social/occupational history –Patient’s goals/inquiry -Document what the patient and caregiver/s hope to accomplish with therapy and in general -Does the family feel they have access to the necessary support? Does the patient receive therapeutic services at home or in school? If so, what is the frequency? -Guidelines of the National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence (United Kingdom) recommend that during the formulation of a program for a child or young person with CP the following issues should be taken into account(59): -The views of the child and his or her parents or caregivers -The likelihood of achieving the treatment goals -Possible difficulties and their implications for the child and his or her parents or caregivers, including time and effort involved and individual barriers –Vocation/avocation and associated repetitive behaviors, if any -Does the child attend school or homeschool? Grade level? Does the child receive special education services? -Is the patient involved in any additional activities, hobbies, and/or sports? How much physical activity does the patient typically participate in everyday? -Is the older patient living independently, working, and/or driving? –Functional limitations/assistance with ADLs/adaptive equipment -What are patient’s primary modes of mobility within the home, school, and outdoor? -Does the patient utilize any assistive or adaptive devices? -How does the patient manage ADLs? -How does the patient manage bowel and bladder function? -Age at which significant developmental milestones were reached, such as sitting, creeping/crawling, feeding oneself, standing, walking, and talking? -How is the patient’s endurance throughout the day? –Living environment -Inquire about number of interior and exterior stairs and floors in the home, with whom patient lives (e.g., primary caregivers, siblings). Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary? Has a home safety inspection been performed? -Is the patient able to safely negotiate all environments (home, school, work)? -Can the child reach the classroom on time? -Are classroom modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting.) Assessment may be more successful and efficient if the therapist follows the child’s lead (e.g., observing the child move spontaneously) where possible, rather than conforming to a specific format.(8) Saving assessment of movements or abilities that are more likely to be negatively affected by spasticity or balance problems until the end of the examination may help keep the child in a cooperative mood as long as  possible. Some tests and measures are age and setting specific; recommendations are a guide and implemented as appropriate for each unique patient
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Anthropometric characteristics –Note height and weight and body mass index (BMI)and compare to age- and sex-matched  growth charts –Assess for leg length discrepancy as indicated. If present, is leg functional or if the discrepancy is true? If the child has a history of a pelvic, femoral, or tibial osteotomy, leg length discrepancy will most likely be true
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Assistive and adaptive devices –What devices does the patient currently use? Assess safety, appropriateness, and fit of devices, and also the need for additional devices -Discomfort, skin injury, and sleep disturbance are more likely to occur if orthoses are designed badly, ill-fitting,  or worn out.(59) Muscle wasting and weakness can develop with long-term  immobilization with orthoses –The Family Impact of Assistive Technology Scale is designed to rate the effect of assistive technology (e.g., postural control devices) on a child with a disability and his/her family. The test is geared towards children who cannot sit independently. Further testing needs to be completed to fully assess the validity and reliability of this new instrument(18)
relevant tests and measures.balance: Balance –Assess static and dynamic balance reactions in all three planes in developmentally appropriate postures (e.g., seated, standing, reaching)(19) –Balance problems in patients with spastic diplegic CP are often due to poor postural responses and reduced anticipatory adjustments(19,20) –The Pediatric Balance Scale (PBS) can be used on patients older than 5 years –The Bruininks-Oseretsky  Test of Motor Proficiency, Second Edition (BOT-2) balance subtest may be used
cardiorespiratory function and endurance: Document vital signs at rest and during mobility
Document distance patient can propel wheelchair (w/c), if appropriate
6-minute  walk for distance test (6MWT) or Timed Up & Go (TUG) test can be used in ambulatory population
Note respiratory rate, use of diaphragm and accessory muscles, atypical breathing patterns, and color changes in lips, skin, and fingers
Does the patient have adequate respiratory support for speech? For movement?
Does respiration adapt to new postural adaptations? -For example, is the child able to speak as well while standing as while sitting?

Describe chest shape and movement of the thorax with breathing -Lack of dynamic trunk alignment can limit physiological shaping of the rib cage if it prevents the ribs from changing their angle at the spine during respiration(8)
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Circulation –Assess bilateral pedal pulse if necessary and appropriate –Note capillary refill time –Note temperature and color of skin Ergonomics/body mechanics –Body mechanics are often impaired; the clinician should document use and effectiveness of various compensatory strategies –Assess primary caregiver’s ability to perform assisted transfers while maintaining proper body mechanics Functional mobility  (including transfers, etc.) –Assess basic functional mobility and note any asymmetries or abnormalities -Deviations during sit-to-stand  transfers may include exaggerated anterior pelvic tilt, premature knee extension, reduced knee extensor moment, decreased muscle force of hip/knee extensors, and increased duration of transfer(21)  -The 1-minute  walk test, 10-meter  walk test, and Lateral Step-Up  test (LSU) can be used as quick, low-cost,  objective functional measures(70) -Researchers in the United States examined the validity and clinical utility of functional assessments on 35 adolescents with spastic tetraplegia and diplegia (Gross Motor Function Measure [GMFM] levels I–III).  The 1-minute  walk test, 10-meter  walk test, and LSU had moderate to high intercorrelations with the GMFM-88.  Researchers concluded these tests could be used for a quick functional assessment but not as a substitute for the GMFM-88(70) –Please see Motor function (motor control/tone/learning) , below
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Gait/locomotion –Gait patterns of children with spastic diplegia can vary greatly depending on the degree of severity of the problem(14) –Individuals with spastic diplegia will typically require assistive devices to achieve ambulation –Authors of a controlled study conducted in the United States involving 30 children with CP (and 27 typically developing peers) and utilizing the Gross Motor Function Classification System (GMFCS) found that the children with CP expend more energy walking than their typically developing peers. (Energy cost was measured by the gas dilution method)(21) -There was a significant correlation to the GMFCS level and the energy cost of walking; the higher the level of disability, the greater the energy expenditure(21) –Instrumented gait analysis, ideally at a computerized motion analysis lab, identifies abnormal gait biomechanics due to spastic muscle patterns and is the gold standard for evaluating gait mechanics in a child with CP(14) -Three Dimensional Gait Analysis (3-DGA)  is used to evaluate gait objectively and is reported to have high intra-rater reliability. Limitations of this method of assessment include the cost and high skill level required to interpret data(22)excessive hip adduction and internal rotation (“scissoring”), increased knee flexion during stance, excessive ankle plantarflexion/ forefoot contact versus heel strike at initial contact, decreased step and stride length(23) -Stiff-knee  gait often occurs in patients who walk with flexed-knee  gait. A flexed-knee  position during stance can dynamically reduce the amount of knee flexion during swing, resulting in a stiff-knee  gait pattern(72) Joint integrity and mobility –There is a high risk of developing joint contractures in children with spasticity since full ROM is difficult to achieve(24); document any joint contractures –Assess upper and lower extremities for joint crepitus –Document presence of any joint hypermobility using the Beighton Hypermobility Scale –Assess hip joint integrity via Galeazzi sign and/or Ortolani maneuver -Galeazzi (or Allis) sign – With the child lying supine, flex the hips and knees and place the feet flat on the table near the buttocks. With the knees together, check the height of the knees. If the knee height is uneven, the lower knee will indicate the leg with hip dysplasia -Ortolani maneuver –Gently  abduct the hip, one leg at a time. If the hip is dislocated, this maneuver reduces the dislocation, which can be felt by the clinician as a click or clunk –A consensus statement on hip surveillance for children with CP endorsed by the Australasian Academy of Cerebral Palsy and Developmental Medicine specifies that routine hip surveillance should be done to reduce morbidity by early identification of hip displacement and risk factors for hip dislocation(73) -Hip dislocation is preventable through early identification and intervention. The goal of hip surveillance is for orthopedic review to occur at the appropriate time -The recommended process includes clinical assessment and radiographs continuing until skeletal maturity, with frequency dependent on GMFCS level, radiographic changes, and age -Increased frequency of hip surveillance is required when hip musculoskeletal measurements have deteriorated (i.e., reduced ROM, reduced muscle length, or changes in muscle tone) or functions such as altered gait and decreased ability or tolerance for sitting or standing have deteriorated -Increased or newly developed asymmetry, or pain related to the hip, requires an increased surveillance or a referral to the orthopedic surgeon Motor function (motor control/tone/learning) –Assess upper and lower extremities and trunk for abnormal tone –Assess spasticity via Modified Ashworth Scale or Tardieu scale  -The Tardieu scale was found to have good to excellent intra-rater  and inter-rater  reliability when used to assess ankle plantar flexors or elbow flexors in a study involving 6 examiners; reliability was increased significantly following a training for 1day(25) -In the year 2013, authors of a systematic review suggest that there is insufficient evidence to recommend the use of a single spasticity assessment tool over another tool. Nineteen studies examining 17 spasticity assessment tools were included. None of the assessment tools demonstrated satisfactory results for all psychometric properties. Furthermore, there was a lack of evidence regarding the absolute reliability, validity, and responsiveness of these tools. Scales such as the Modified Ashworth and Tardieu scale, which use ordinal scales, provide poor accuracy and reliability. Neurophysiological tools(e.g., EMG, electrogoniometrics, and myometric data) had the best results for reliability and discriminating validity; however, these tools are expensive and not readily available to most clinicians(67) –Spasticity is most often found in hip flexors, adductors, and internal rotators and ankle plantar flexors(20) –Assess for bilateral ankle clonus and indicate the number of beats present –Describe the child’s movement(8) -Spontaneous movement -Atypical movement patterns -Impact of weight-bearing  on movement
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Muscle strength –Use manual muscle test (MMT) or handheld dynamometry (HHD) as indicated; assess strength through function in the younger population or with those who are unable to follow commands of testing -MMT is not valid for muscles with contractures or abnormal tone, or when coordination is impaired -In the presence of increased muscle tone, the patient will have difficulty isolating individual muscle groups against gravity. Document whether the patient can isolate a muscle in anti-gravity  positions –Results of a study conducted in the Netherlands indicate that HHD strength measurements are reliable to use in children with CP. HHD measurements are sufficiently sensitive to detect changes in isometric muscle strength when a mean of at least 2 trials is taken(61) -A total of 14 children, 8 with spastic diplegia and 6 with spastic hemiplegia, were included –Ankle dorsiflexors in individuals with CP have approximately 50% of normal strength,and plantar flexors have approximately 35% of normal strength(31) –In a retrospective, cross-sectional  study conducted in the United States involving 97 patients with spastic diplegic CP, authors have suggested muscle strength to be highly correlated to physical functioning, but there was little correlation to spasticity (using the GMFM-66  to assess physical function and the KinCom dynamometer to assess spasticity and muscle strength). Patients assessed were all ambulatory, and some used assistive devices(32) Neuromotor development –Assess age-appropriate  functional skills and note movement patterns -Developmental milestones are often delayed, starting with rolling, due to the child’s inability to isolate muscle groups against gravity and without tone interfering with the necessary motor control for the movement (e.g., hip abductors and hip extensors are needed to roll in either direction successfully)(14) -Reciprocal creeping (crawling on hands and knees) is often difficult for a child with spastic diplegic CP due to increased tone; the child often commando crawls -Independent sitting is delayed often and compensatory strategies develop to counteract increased lower extremity tone and trunk hypotonia; the upper extremities are used often for additional supportGross Motor Function Measure (GMFM), Test of Infant Motor Performance (TIMP), WeeFIM, Peabody Developmental Motor Scales, Second Edition (PDMS-2),  Alberta Infant Motor Scale (AIMS), and Pediatric Evaluation of Disability Inventory (PEDI) -TIMP is a clinical tool designed for infants 32 weeks gestational age to 4 months adjusted age. Validity is high, and the tool can be used to document progress in postural and motor control(26) -WeeFIM is reported to be a useful clinical tool in assessing self-care, sphincter control, transfers and locomotion, and communication and social cognition(27) -PDMS-2  has good test-retest  reliability over 1 week and appropriate responsiveness and sensitivity to change over 3 months based on a noncontrolled study conducted in Taiwan involving 32 children with CP(28)  -Treatment goals of 36 pediatric physical therapists (PTs) who were treating children with CP in the Netherlands were analyzed. The goals were then linked to the PEDI or the GMFM-88,  and researchers found that approximately 86% of the physical therapy goals could be represented by these tools and therefore be utilized as outcome measures(29) -Authors of a study conducted in the Netherlands investigating the responsiveness of the GMFM-88  and the PEDI in 55 children with CP (2–7years of age) found both were able to detect alterations in motor performance over a period and that these tools were most sensitive in children under the age of 4 years(30)
observation inspection palpation includi: Assess skin integrity, noting any redness, ability to blanch, presence of skin breakdown, and size. Indicate stage of wounds, if present, and notify primary/referring physician. Pay particular attention to skin contact with any orthoses. Document orthosis wearing schedule

Complete a general observation of contact/communication between child and parents/caregivers(8) -Where applicable, observe how the parent/caregiver handle the child -Does the child receive and respond to verbal input from the parent/caregiver? -How does the child respond to eye contact from the parent/caregiver? •Perception  (e.g., visual field, spatial relations)(8)
Visual acuity should be screened as indicated
A referral to an ophthalmologist (for overall eye health) and/or developmental optometrist (for functional vision assessment) may be warranted
Visual-Motor  Integration (VMI) may be tested using the Developmental Test of VMI (also called Beery VMI)
relevant tests and measures.posture: Posture –Assess posture in sitting and standing and with and without braces. Assess individual’s sitting posture in a wheelchair, if indicated. Note any postural asymmetries and any compensatory postures(8) –Note the patient’s ability to maintain head control and midline orientation in all positions (prone, supine, sitting, standing) –Observe for signs of scoliosis (rib hump, shoulder elevation, pelvic asymmetry)(14) -20–25%  of individuals with CP will develop scoliosis -Note whether the curves are structural or functional –Note whether the child avoids certain postures during spontaneous activity –Note resistance to placement into specific postures –Note any atypical postures that precede weight-bearing  or movement initiation –If an infant, determine ability to maintain various positions in which he or she is placed
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Range of motion –Assess bilateral passive and active upper and lower extremity ROM; use goniometry -Passive ROM is significantly limited in children with spastic CP compared with children with typical development; typically, children with spastic CP will have reduced passive ROM in the hamstrings, hip adductor, iliopsoas, and gastrocnemius-soleus  musculature(33)hip abduction with knees flexed and extended, ankle flexion with knees flexed and extended; and Thomas test position for hip extension, and knee extension using the popliteal angle position(6) -Elbow extension and wrist supination and extension may be limited due to biceps brachii spasticity –Active ROM can be informally assessed through movement if the child is resistive to handling, nonverbal, or has difficulty following commands –Authors of a randomized controlled trial conducted in New Zealand involving 25 patients with spastic diplegic CP found significant variation in ROM measurements via goniometry(34) -Within the same session, mean absolute differences in measurements in the group with CP were 1–4.2° -Between sessions, the mean absolute differences were up to 7.1° for children with CP -A change of 15–20°  was necessary to have 95% confidence that there was a true change in ROM Reflex integrity/protective reactions testing –Assess for anterior, posterior, and lateral protective reactions in sitting, prone, and standing as indicated -Even a minimal upper extremity impairment may limit protective reactions –Assess for primitive reflexes (such as the Moro, Babinski, asymmetrical tonic neck, parachute) that may be abnormally absent or persistent -If there is no upper extremity involvement, parachute reactions should be intact  –Turning the child’s head may cause tonal changes in the lower extremities(14) –Assess bilateral deep tendon reflexes, which are often hyper-reflexive Self-care/activities  of daily living  (objective testing) –Evaluate or inquire about ADLs; note any assistive devices used –PEDI may be used to assist with assessing patient and/or family perception of ADL limitations
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Sensory testing –Stereognosis, joint position sense, and two-point  discrimination are impaired often in children with CP(35) -Researchers who conducted a prospective cross-sectional  study in the United States involving 62 children with CP -Sensory testing comprised of light touch, position sense, vibration sense, direction of scratch, and pain sensation can begin as young as 5 years in children with CP -When comparing the children with CP to typically developing children, significant impairments were detected in the ability of children with CP to perceive the great toe position, direction of scratch, and vibration -When comparing a subgroup of children with spastic diplegic CP to the typically developing children, there was a significant impairment in the ability to perceive pinprick and direction of the scratch
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Arousal, attention, cognition (including memory, problem-solving) –Assess orientation x 4 (name, place, date, situation) as age, cognitive and developmental level allow –Assess ability to follow commands; determine how many steps the patient can follow with a given command –The Neonatal Behavioral Assessment Scale may be used with newborns –Note any adaptive communication devices used by child/family

Patients with this diagnosis are at risk for falls; if inpatient, follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post-fall prevention instructions at the bedside. Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary below is meant to serve as a guide and not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols

Electrotherapy  contraindications/precautions include(when approved by the treating physician, electrotherapy may be used in the presence of few of the circumstances listed below if the benefits outweigh the perceived risk)(36)

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Diagnosis/need for treatment Most individuals with CP will require periodic courses of physical therapy throughout their lives, with the degree/intensity varying depending on the child’s needs. Intervention should be tailored to meet the needs of the child/family at each particular stage of development as well as postsurgical procedures, antispasticity interventions, and/or joint contracture management. The facets of physical therapy intervention are numerous but generally include prevention of musculoskeletal deformity, maximizing mobility/function, pain management, and patient/family education
assessment plan of care.rule out: Rule out Progressive neurologic disorder Idiopathic toe-walkingX-linked  genetic disorder, slowly progressive, begins in infancy Traumatic brain injury Cerebellar or cerebral tumor
prognosis: As a child ages, the neuromotor impairments will impact his or her functional skills. For example, gait efficiency often decreases, resulting in the need for increased assistive devices and/or a wheelchair as the primary means of mobility

Prognosis depends on the child’s IQ, severity of motor deficits, and degree of incapacity(56) –Patients with mild CP may improve with age –Many children with normal intellect have normal lifespans and can lead productive lives –Aspiration pneumonia or other infections are the most common causes of death

Predictors of inability to walk independently in children with CP include an IQ less than 50, the presence of active epilepsy, and a severe visual and/or hearing impairment(37) –Based on a record review of 9,012 children with CP born in Europe between the years 1976 and 1996 –At age 5 years, 54% could walk unaided, 16% could walk with aids, and 30% were unable to walk

Independent predictors of the ability to walk a minimum of 20 feet independently in children with CP include sitting and/or pulling to stand at 2 years of age, type of CPother than spastic quadriparesis, and intact visual function(38) –Based on a retrospective study conducted in the United States of 2,295 children with CP who were not walking at age 2–3.5  years and evaluated at age 6 years –At the age of 6 years, 12.8% could walk independently (at least 20 feet) and 18.4% walked with support
As the nervous system matures, some resolution of symptoms may be seen early in the child’s life(3)

A cross-sectional  study conducted in the Netherlands of 54 adults with CP aged 25–36  years assessed health concerns in this population(39) –Fifty-nine  percent of group sample reported pain  –Fifteen percent had a joint deformity in their most affected upper extremity –Fifty-seven  percent had a joint deformity in their most affected lower extremity –Approximately 20% had swallowing and speech impairments –Twenty-two  percent of the group sampled had vision concerns

The majority of children with CP aged 8–12  years have a quality of life similar to that of children without CP(40) –Based on a study of 500 children throughout Europe aged 8–12  years with CP –The children with CP who were able to participate in the quality of life assessment did not have a severe intellectual impairment
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplinesTypically The goal of surgery in this population is to improve ROM, correct musculoskeletal deformities, reduce pain, and improve overall function(41) –Researchers in Brazil conducted a retrospective chart review study that included 21 patients with spastic CP (10 of whom had diplegia) with planovalgus deformities of the foot. They found that 34/35 of the feet operated on (97%) showed improvement of deformity including the elimination of foot pain following medial column arthrodesis surgery(42) –Researchers in France conducted a study that included 45 patients with spastic diplegia CP and stiff-knee  gait (resulting from reduced ROM in the knee). They found that all patients had improved knee ROM after rectus femoris distal tendon resection at short-term  follow-up  (2 years post surgery)(43) –To determine the effects of selective dorsal rhizotomy (SDR) on upper extremity muscle tone and function, researchers in the United States conducted a retrospective chart review that included 42 children with spastic CP who underwent SDR. They found 25/42 of these children had upper extremity spasticity; and after the SDR, 23/25 children had improvements of at least 1 point on the Modified Ashworth Scale in 2 or more muscle groups. Furthermore, 17 families completed a survey,and 71% of these parents reported their children had improved motor control. Researchers concluded that children with a mean preoperative upper extremity tone of 1.25–1.75  on the Modified Ashworth Scale were most likely to benefit from a reduction in tone following SDR(68)Many anecdotal reports of psychosocial issues were reported in the literature as parents and children try to cope with the effects of CP. A referral to a specialist may be warranted, and each case should be evaluated on an individual basis. The clinician needs to avoid generalizations based on the level of impairment and assess the needs of each family separatelyIf feeding or speech concerns are present, a speech and swallowing evaluation is indicated Vision therapist Adaptive technology specialist Orthotist(59)
treatment summary: A common recommendation in the literature reviewed is that the clinician should focus on increasing muscle strength in conjunction with spasticity reduction to improve overall function

The interventions listed below are from studies specific to children with spastic diplegic CP; for general or nonstandard interventions, please refer to other Clinical Reviews related to CP listed under Presentation/signs and symptoms

Therapeutic exercise –Researchers in India conducted a randomized controlled study to investigate the effects of functional strength training on functional motor performance in young children with spastic diplegia. Weight-bearing  exercises involving the lower extremity in support and balance were performed that had similar characteristics to functional activities (44) -Eighteen children aged 5–10  years participated -Following a 4-week  exercise program that included bilateral heel raises, sit to stand, standing balance exercises, step-ups,  and ball- supported half squats, the intervention group had significant improvements in functional strength and performance scores. The control group did no training and did not show any significant improvements -Significant improvements were seen in lateral step-up  tests, sit to stand item on the motor assessment scale, minimum height chair test scores, and in walking speed. The improvements were reported to be maintained at follow up, although the length of follow up was not identified -Further research with a larger sample size appears warranted  –Researchers in the United States conducted a small randomized controlled trial involving 15 children with spastic diplegic CP to investigate the effect of ankle strengthening on gait and overall function. This pilot study demonstrated that the ankle strengthening may improve function and gait(31) -Data from 3 subjects were excluded for various reasons; final results were from 12 subjects -Comprised of 4 groups: plantar flexor (PF) strength training group; dorsiflexor (DF) strength training group; PF and DF strength training group; and control group -Training groups experienced: -Significant changes in muscle strength (measured via dynamometer) -Significant improvement in the GMFM-88  walk-run  dimension and quality of life measure –Researchers in Taiwan conducted a randomized controlled trial involving 20 children with spastic diplegic CP to investigate the effectiveness of loaded sit-to-stand  (STS) resistance exercises and found significant improvements in the 1 repetition maximum of STS, GMFM-88  goal dimension scores, and physiological cost index(45) -Both the control and treatment groups participated in regular physical therapy regimens; the treatment group additionally performed loaded STS exercises 3 time per week for 6 weeks -Isometric knee extensor strength and gait speed did not change significantly in the treatment group when compared to the control group –Authors of a randomized controlled trial conducted in Australia involving 21 children with spastic diplegic CP investigated the impact of a home-based strength training routine (heel raises, half squats, step-ups).  The study found significantly improved lower limb strength at 12 weeks after the 6-week training(46) -The treatment group exercised 3 times a week for 6 weeks -Children in the study were aged 8–18  years and were independent or modified independent ambulators (with/without assistive device use) –With the combination of botulinum Toxintype-A  (BoNT-A)  and strength training, children with CP can get improvements in muscle size and muscle strength simultaneous with a reduction in spasticity(62) -Based on a study conducted in Australia -Fifteen children with spastic diplegic CP were randomized to 10 weeks of strength training either before or after receiving BoNT-A.  Children were assessed over 6 months -Significant strength improvements associated with hypertrophy were seen at 10 weeks and over 6 months -The study showed that muscles injected with BoNT-A  can be successfully strengthened –Continuous passive motion (CPM) of the knees can reduce spastic hypertonia and improve ambulation in children with spastic CP(47) -Based on a research study conducted in Taiwan with 16 children (ages 6–12 years) with spastic CP (11 had spastic diplegia and 5 had spastic quadriplegia)(47) -Each participant completed an intervention session and a control session on separate days(47) -Researchers used a self-designed  CPM device to provide CPM to the participants’ knee joints at a peak angular velocity of 15° per second(47) -The session included 20 minutes of CPM of the knee joints during which time participants watched self-selected cartoons(47) -During the control session, a subject’s knee was held stationary in 20–30°  flexion for 20 minutes(47) -Measurements of active and passive ROM of the knee and ankle joints, Pendulum test, MAS, two trials of TUG, and the 6MWT were completed before the intervention (time 1), immediately after the intervention (time 2), and 30 minutes after the intervention (time 3)(47) -Significant improvements in MAS, TUG, and 6MWT scores were found at time 2 and time 3after the intervention, but not after the control sessions; also, significant improvements of active ROM was seen after the intervention at time 2 and 3(47)

Physical Fitness –Investigators in the Netherlands found that lifestyle intervention is effective for improving cardiopulmonary fitness and body composition in adolescents and young adults with spastic CP(74) -Based on a single-blind  randomized controlled trial that involved 57 participants with spastic CP classified in GMFCS levels I through IV  -Forty-two  participants completed the study; of these, approximately half were diplegic -Participants were randomized to an active lifestyle and sports participation intervention group or to a control group that received no intervention to improve physical behavior and fitness -The active lifestyle and sports participation consisted of 3 parts: -Three months of weekly supervised center and weekly home-based physical training with a focus on increasing levels of cardiopulmonary fitness and muscle strength, supervised by a physical therapist -Counseling on daily physical activity (PA) based on motivational interviewing by a personal coach (physical therapist or movement therapist), aimed at increasing PA and minimizing sedentary behavior -Counseling on sports participation to find accessible and appropriate sports and sports facilities in each participant’s environment -Outcome measures included peak oxygen consumption, body composition, and muscle strength -Measurements were performed4 times: before randomization, after the fitness training (3 months), after the entire intervention including counseling (6 months), and at the6 months follow-up  after the intervention -The results suggest that offering a lifestyle intervention has positive results on physical fitness -The intervention group had positive short-  and medium-term  effects on VO 2 peak oxygen consumption, and load on the anaerobic threshold, and waist circumference. Long-term  effects on the sum of skinfolds, systolic blood pressure, and total cholesterol were also obtained -The intervention was ineffective in increasing muscle strength. The authors concluded that the program needs to be optimized to increase muscle strength and also for long-term  retention of aerobic capacity improvements

Seated positioning –Bimanual-powered  wheelchair system may improve a child’s seated postural alignment compared to a traditional unilateral-powered  device(66) -Based on a study conducted in Taiwan of 20 children with spastic CP (11 subjects with diplegia and 9 with quadriplegia) and a mean age of 7.7 years compared to children without any medical conditions -All children drove the powered wheelchair in both the unimanual and bimanual joystick modes,and researchers assessed postural alignment with the Seated Postural Control Measure -Children with CP demonstrated greater symmetrical alignment with the bimanual mode compared to the unilateral mode -The control group demonstrated greater postural alignment compared to the children with CP for both driving modes -The severity of CP moderately correlated with postural symmetry in both modes –Seat surface inclination may affect the postural control and reach in preterm children with CP(48) -Based on a study conducted in the Netherlands of 58 children aged 2–11 years with spastic CP -Surface electromyographic and kinematic data were recorded while the children were sitting and reaching under 3 different conditions -Horizontal (no tilt) seat surface -Seat surface tilted forward 15° -Seat surface tilted backward 15° -Forward-tilted  seating position appeared better for postural control and reach in 34 children with unilateral spastic CP -Horizontal seating position appeared better for postural control and reach in 24 children with bilateral spastic CP

Balance training –In a small noncomparative study conducted in the United States of 6 children with CP (4 with spastic diplegia, 2 with spastic hemiplegia) who underwent 5 days of intensive balance training, consisting of 100 perturbations per day on a moveable force platform, the following findings were reported:(49) -In the children with spastic diplegia, the start of muscle contractions were late in the lower extremities once perturbations commenced; however, timing improved in certain muscles post training -Before training, the muscles contracted in a pattern of proximal to distal, which is the opposite of the pattern seen in typically developing children. However, after training this pattern reversed to the desired outcome of distal to proximal in 2 of the children but was not sustained at 1 month -An enhancement in the ability to control the amplitude of muscle activity was also observed in the patients with spastic diplegia, but this positive finding was seen in just 2 of the subjects at 1 month

W/C management –The following recommendations were made based on a year 2006 literature review on the effect of w/c positioning on upper extremity function in children with CP(50)  -The child’s pelvis should be held in neutral position -A functional sitting position (FSO) is recommended for facilitating the use of the child’s upper extremities -FSO – hip belt, abduction orthosis, a cutout tray, footrests, and orientation in the space of 0–15° -A forward sloped seat of 0–15° -The child’s head, shoulders, and trunk should be positioned slightly anterior to the ischial tuberosities

Treadmill training(51,52) –Partial body weight supported treadmill training has recently been reported to be a safe and effective method for improving gait speed in children with cerebral palsy(51) -In a randomized controlled trial conducted in the United States comparing the effects of strengthening exercise and supported treadmill training, 26 children with cerebral palsy were randomly assigned to 12 weeks of intensive exercise based on impairments and functional tasks with an emphasis on standing weight-bearing  activities, or to 12 weeks of supported speed treadmill training -Gait speed, cadence and physical function as measured by the parent report for the Pediatric Outcomes Data Collection Instrument (PODCI) improved in both groups, with no significant difference between groups -Only the treadmill training group maintained the gains after the withdrawal of intervention(51) –Recent advances in body weight support technology may improve the therapeutic protocols used for gait training in children with CP. Traditionally the body weight is supported with a chest corset that has straps under the groin or around the proximal thighs. These straps may be uncomfortable and limit the duration of and compliance with the training session(52) -Lower body positive pressure supported (LBPPS) treadmill training has been developed as an alternative means for supporting the body weight -A treadmill is enclosed in an inflatable (pressurized) bag. The child wears a pair of neoprene shorts that are zipped into the bag, and the amount of body weight supported is dependent upon the air pressure of the bag. Since the air pressure is uniformly distributed over the lower body it reduces the uncomfortable pressure points that often occur in traditional body weight support systems -Results of a feasibility study conducted in the United States with 9 participants indicate that LBPPS treadmill training is a feasible method to improve walking performance, balance, and strength of children with CP(52)

Robotic training –Investigators in the United States found that a rehabilitation protocol for patients with CP that used a robotic ankle device for ankle stretching and strengthening resulted in significant improvements(75) -Participants were 28 children with GMFCS levels I–III.  There was no control group -All patients were seen twice per week for 75-minute  sessions for a total of 6 weeks. The intervention consisted of 30 minutes using the robotic ankle device for stretching and strengthening, followed by 45-minutes  of functional movement activities -Outcome measures included measures of plantarflexor and dorsiflexor ROM, strength, spasticity, mobility (using the TUG test, 6MWT, and 10MWT), balance (using the pediatric balance scale), selective control assessment of the lower extremity (SCALE), and the GMFM -Significant improvements were seen for all main outcome measures except the GMFM

Video games –Children with spastic diplegic CP can obtain exercise-related  benefits while playing with an active video game console (e.g., Wii games)(63) -Results of a study conducted in Canada that compared exercise intensity in children with spastic diplegia and children who were typically developing showed no difference between the groups while they played 4 active video games (jogging, bicycling, snowboarding, and skiing)(63) -Ten children with spastic diplegic CP and 10 age-matched  children who were typically developing were evaluated playing 4 video games for 40 minutes. HR was recorded for the entire time using a HR belt monitor -The amount of time spent at an intensity greater than 40% of heart rate reserve (HRR) was recorded -Active video game consoles appear to be an affordable, safe, and fun way to improve aerobic capacity in children with CP

Neurodevelopmental treatment (NDT) –NDT may not be more effective than other therapeutic strategies in the rehabilitative treatment of individuals with CP(53)  -Based on the report by the American Academy for Cerebral Palsy and Developmental Medicine -A more intense NDT program may not yield better outcomes than standard frequency of treatment -Task-oriented  approaches, strengthening, endurance training, and the use of assistive technologies may yield better results, but more research is needed to support this –NDT 5 times per week might be more effective than 2 times per week for improving function in children with CP(54) -Based on a small randomized trial conducted in Greece -Thirty-four  children were randomized to NDT twice a week for 16 weeks vs. NDT 5 times a week for 16 weeks -Sessions were 50 minutes long in each group -Both treatment groups had significant improvements in gross motor function after the 16-week  treatment regimen according to the GMFM-88 -The group that underwent intensive (5 days per week) therapy had a greater improvement in function

Orthotics –Wearing hinged AFOs during sit-to-stand  (STS) transfers was reported to improve the transfer in a study conducted in South Korea(21) -Nineteen children with spastic diplegic CP completed STS transfers with hinged AFOs and without (barefoot) -Subjects were aged 2–6 years -While wearing the AFO -Duration of transfer was significantly reduced -Initial dorsiflexion and knee flexion angle were significantly increased -Dorsiflexion end range was significantly increased -The maximum power of hip extension and knee extension was significantly increased -Hip and pelvis movements did not differ significantly from barefoot trials -Plantarflexion power did not differ significantly .
